basics.name: Bharat Singhal
basics.Current position: PhD Candidate in System Science & Mathematics
basics.summary: Interested in developing control-theoretic methods for controlling large-scale networks arising from biological applications

courses: Optimization, Introduction to Machine Learning, Theory of Statistics, Measure Theory and Functional Analysis, High-Dimensional Statistics, Linear Dynamical Systems, Nonlinear Systems
Programming and Data Structure, Probability & Stochastic Process, Data Structure and Algorithms, Digital Control
Signal & Networks, Switching & Finite Automata, Control Theory

work.name: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC)
work.summary: RC Interconnect Modeling for Sub 10nm CMOS Technology Nodes
highlights: Integrated different SOC designs like ASIC on ASIC (AOA), system on integrated chip (SOIC) and wafer on wafer (WOW) to implement 3D-IC RC tech files for 7nm and 12nm nodes

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'

publications.name: Optimal Phase-Selective Entrainment of Heterogeneous Oscillator Ensembles
publications.publisher: SIAM Journal on Applied Dynamical Systems
publications.summary: We design optimal entrainment signals that entrain an ensemble of heterogeneous nonlinear oscillators at desired phases.

publications.name: Iterative Approach to Optimal Control Design for Oscillator Networks
publications.summary: We design time or energy-optimal controls for a network of coupled neurons. This work proposes a unified framework that offers the flexibility to blend the time-optimal and energy-optimal considerations with a parameter of choice.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
